1 Abstract: Flexible solid-state supercapacitors possess promising safety performance and intrinsic fast charging/discharging properties, enabling to accomplish requirements for lightweight and multifunctional wearable electronics in recently. Because electrode materials are the core component of flexible solid-state supercapacitors, we extensively review the recent exploits on the electrode materials of carbons, metal oxides and conductive polymers. The principles and methods of optimizing and fabricating electrodes for flexible supercapacitor are discussed through a comprehensive analysis of the literature. In addition, we focused on three type of flexible solid-state supercapacitors (including fiber-like, paper-like and porous foam-like structures) to satisfy the demand of flexible electronic devices. We also summarize the practical applications of flexible solid-state supercapacitors, including energy conversion/collection devices and energy storage/detection devices. Finally, we provide a development direction for flexible solid-state supercapacitors in the future. Keyword: Flexible supercapacitors; Electrode materials; Device design; Wearable electronics.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Supercapacitors, also called ultracapacitors, play irreplaceable role in some applications, such as low-power electronic equipment, electric and hybrid vehicles, renewable energy.1 The supercapacitors are developed since in the 1960s.2 However, the supercapacitors attach importance to grow up of hybrid electric vehicles in the 1990s.3 Comparing to the traditional capacitors and batteries, the supercapacitor is proved as a green and prominent energy storage device with capacity of 100-1000 Farads. Although the energy density of supercapacitors is small, its power density and cycle life are much larger than that of a battery.4, 5 In recent years, the development of supercapacitors technology has been successfully used in consumer electronics, energy transportation, power compensation and other fields, and the market scale is rapidly expanding. With the ever-increasing demands of portable and wearable electronics, it is crucial to develop flexible devices that can store the energy. Therefore, the mechanics-flexible supercapacitors become a strong candidate among various energy devices. The supercapacitors are mainly composed of separator, electrode, electrolyte and current collector. As the core component of supercapacitors, the electrode materials and electrolytes become the research hotspots in recently. There are three types of supercapacitors including electric double layers capacitors (EDLCs),6 pseudocapacitors7 and hybrid supercapacitors in terms of the energy storage mechanism.8 EDLCs can store energy by acquiring charge accumulation at the electrode-electrolyte interface via an electrostatic interaction. Therefore, the carbon electrode materials are mostly developed to improve the performance of EDLCs because of the high surface areas.9 In contrast, the pseudocapacitors stores electrons through a reversible faradaic reaction also occurring on

3 the interface of electrode/electrolyte, which possess higher energy than that of EDLCs. The transition metal oxides materials and the conducting polymers materials are often regarded as potential active electrode materials for pseudocapacitors.10 To receive the high energy density and power density at the same time, researchers began to design hybrid supercapacitors, which are made up of the combination of EDLCs and pseudocapacitors. However, the combining the advantages of EDLCs and pseudocapacitive materials remains challenge because of their intrinsically anisotropic properties and diverse preparation approaches.11 The crucial task of constructing excellent performance of supercapacitors is to search promising electrode materials. Over the past few decades, various electrode materials such as carbons,12 metals,13 transition metal oxides,14 metal oxides/hydroxide,15 conductive polymer materials16 and their composite materials have been extensively studied to manufacture supercapacitors. Flexible and wearable functions are considered important features for the next generation of electronic products. Therefore, the development of flexible supercapacitor as an energy device becomes urgent for wearable electronic applications. The flexible supercapacitor is an energy storage device, which could maintain stable performance under various deformation conditions.17, 18 In general, the current flexible tests of flexible supercapacitor mainly focus on different deformation status, such as bending,19 folding,20 twisting,21 stretching,22 etc. The bending test of flexible supercapacitor is investigated by bending to a variety of degrees (0°-180°). The folding/unfolding and twisting test of the electrode is examined via creasing several hundred times. The stretching test is a fatigue test after stretching certain cycles of the electrode under different strains. There are two

4 important directions in development of flexible supercapacitors fields: one is increasing the specific capacitance of electrode materials, which often used to promote the electrochemical performance of the flexible supercapacitors. Another is optimizing the construction structure of the flexible supercapacitor, enhancing the deformation ability of the flexible device. In general, there are three main structures for flexible supercapacitor, including fiber-like, paper/fabric-like and foam-like structures. According to the contact form of electrode and electrolyte, it can be divided into "sandwich" structure and plane interdigital structure. It is important to select and design a suitable device structure to realize the performance requirements of the flexible supercapacitors.23 The electrochemical characteristics of flexible supercapacitors generally include power density, capacitance, energy density, and its cycling life. The specific capacitance (Cs, F/g) reflects the amount of capacitance of the unit electrode material. The computational formula from the galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) curves are showing as follows:24 Cs =(IΔt)/(mΔV) (1) The Cs, can also be calculated by the integral area (S) of the cyclic voltammogram (CV) curves: Cs= S/2mυΔV (2) Where Δt, ΔV, I, m, and υ are the discharge time, potential window, discharge current, the mass and scan rates, respectively. The area ratio capacitance (CA, F/cm2) and volumetric specific capacitance (Cv, F/cm3) can be obtained by replacing the m to areal and volumetric of the electrode. The calculation of the areal energy density (E) and power density (P) are showing as

When the energy density of the supercapacitors is the same, the greater power density represents the faster charged and discharged performance of the supercapacitors. In general, an intact two-electrode ultracapacitor cell consists mainly with two electrodes that connected by separator (Fig. 1). The separator can effectively isolate the positive and negative electrodes, preventing the migration of electrons and ensuring ion exchange of the electrodes. With the different requirement of the supercapacitor, there are various design devices by using an unit cells such as paper, fiber plastics, etc.26

We comprehensively introduce the study of various electrode materials and the structure design of device, then also review their integration applications in wearable electronics.

Our discussion begins with the structure design of the electrodes to preparation the desired electrochemical performance of flexible supercapacitors. The recent progresses of fabricated electrode materials for typical flexible supercapacitors are introduced in detail. According to their structures and pattern designs, the existing flexible supercapacitors are illustrated from three types: fiber-like flexible supercapacitors, paper-like flexible supercapacitors and porous foam-like flexible supercapacitors (Fig. 2). Finally, we proposed the future development trends of flexible supercapacitors. We envision that this review will become a comprehensive source of information in this field, promoting the development of electrode materials and further facilitating its practical application for flexible supercapacitors.

sections.heading: 2.1. Carbon materials
sections.text:
The synthesis of electrode materials with favorable electrochemical performance and mechanical stability is vital to construct flexible supercapacitors. Carbon materials mainly including active carbon, carbon nanotubes (CNTs)27, graphene8, 28, 29 and their composites30 etc. are developed as flexible supercapacitor electrode materials because of their good electrical properties (104-105 S/cm), excellent mechanical strength, and large specific surface area (1250-3000 m2/g). The synthetic processes of carbon materials are relatively simple, and most carbon materials are environmental-friendly and inexpensive. Activated carbon is the most widely used active electrode material in EDLCs with the characteristics of high specific surface area (as high as 3000 m2/g) and abundant source. Although the theoretical capacitance of the activated carbon can be as high as 600 F/g, the actual specific capacitance of the activated carbon electrode in the aqueous electrolyte is only 75-250 F/g. Indeed, the specific capacitance of active carbon materials not only depends on the specific surface area, but also relevant to the pore size distribution and structure of active carbon materials. An activated carbon of coconut shell is introduced by the two times activation treatment with the numerous pores. The diameter distribution of the pores increases from 0.6-0.8 nm to 1-3 nm, and the specific capacitance of the activated carbon increases from 140 to 240 F/g at the same current density because the electrolyte can rapidly migrate in a developed mesoporous structure.31 These results emphasize that it is efficient to tune the porosity of the activated carbon electrode to improve both surface area and electrolyte migration (matching pore size of electrode and

8 ion size).32 In addition, the high specific surface area of activated carbon is also suitable for expanding the effective surface area of other metal oxide electrodes. The composite electrode of NiO and activated carbon is developed. The surface areas of NiO increases from 150 m2/g to 575 m2/g, as well as the capacitance is improved from 20 F/g of the NiO to 100 F/g.33 In addition to improving its own electrochemical performance, the research of activated carbon electrode materials can also be combined with other materials with excellent properties to meet the requirements of practical supercapacitor applications. As a typical one-dimensional structural nanomaterial, CNTs possess large surface area, outstanding electrical and mechanical network properties.34 The current density of CNT could tolerate as high as 109 A/cm2 that is 1000 times of noble metals. Typically, the capacitances range of bare CNTs electrode is from 5 to 200 F/g.35 The network structure of CNT also has favorable robustness in various deformation states. For example, a flexible supercapacitor is fabricated based on bacterial nano-cellulose papers and CNTs. The specific capacitance of the CNTs electrode is 50.5 F/g (∼20.2 mF/cm2), and the energy density is 15.5 mWh/g. The supercapacitor has promising cycle stability with 0.5% decreasing of capacitance after 5000 cycles.36 Subsequently, the surface modification, defects introduction and heteroatoms doping method (such as N37, B38, S39, or P40) have been developed to effectively boost the performance of CNT-based materials. For instance, N-doping mesoporous carbon nanofiber is designed and fabricated for flexible supercapacitors. The high capacity (327.3 F/g) of this as-synthesized carbon nanofiber electrode is ascribed to the increasing active sites of the materials with the high degree of nitrogen-doping.41 However, the low power density of pure CNT is still difficult to

9 support the high energy density requirement for flexible supercapacitors. Therefore, integrating synergistic effect between pseudo-capacitive nanomaterial and CNT are considered as a valid means to increase the capacitance of CNT electrode. The CNT-based composite electrodes such as CNT/polymer composite42-45 and CNT/metallic oxide hybrids are emerged as reasonable choice for flexible supercapacitors.46-48 Graphene, as another carbon material with extraordinary electrical conductivity and mechanical properties, has become significant research hotspots in the fabrication of flexible supercapacitors. Especially, the high theoretical specific surface area and capacitance value of graphene electrode is high up to 2675 m2/g and 550 F/g, respectively.49 However, the agglomeration of graphene sheets is an obstacle in the preparation and application process. To mitigate these practical problems, the micro-porosity structure graphene electrode material is expected to an effective strategy. A most meaningful study is fabricated porous graphene (pore diameters of 0.6-5 nm) via KOH. The specific surface area of the porous electrode can reach to 3000 m2/g, and the specific capacitance also is high to 170 F/g.50 Moreover, the nitrogen doping of porous graphene (N-Gr) has developed to facilitate charge transfer rates for flexible supercapacitors. The specific capacitance of the fabricated N-Gr electrode materials is 390 F/g and specific surface area is 203 m2 /g.51 Apart from using pure graphene as electrode materials, the combination of graphene with active materials is another strategy to realize pseudo-capacitance for flexible supercapacitors. For example, graphene/polyaniline (PANI) composite paper electrode is fabricated by in situ electrodepositing the polyaniline film onto graphene paper, which

superior performance strongly suggested the critical importance of integrating porous

sections.heading: 2.2. Metal oxides
sections.text:
Carbon materials has widely used as EDLCs electrodes. However, lower specific capacity
limits their applications. In this point, the pseudocapacitive electrode materials of metal
oxide are developed to increase the capacity of flexible supercapacitors. Pseudocapacitors
are not only generated on the surface of electrode, but also the inside of entire electrode
and could gain higher capacitance (10-100 times) than that of the EDLCs in the case of the same electrode areas.54 The metal oxide electrode possessed long life (105-106 cycles) and
simple maintenance, which is a considerable type of energy storage materials with high
efficiency and practicality, attracting wide attention in recently. At present, metal oxide
electrode materials are mainly divided into noble metal oxides and transition-metal oxides in flexible supercapacitors.55, 56

2.2.1. RuO2 nanoparticles. The study of noble metal oxide electrodes mainly focus on ruthenium oxide (RuO2), which exhibit good conductivity and high theoretical specific capacitance among pseudocapacitive materials (1360 F/g for RuO2·0.5H2O).57 RuO2 is the first discovered pseudocapacitive properties of electrode materials with better conductivity than that of the carbon electrode by Conway et al.58 The involved reactions of the pseudocapacitive of RuO2 materials are not identical in different electrolytes.59, 60 The corresponding reaction mechanism in the acidic electrolyte is as showing.
(5)-2 2 x xRuO + xH+ xe RuO (OH)
With the transfer of electrons, the proton is also participated in the process. The oxidation states of Ru(II) can change to Ru(IV).61
However, it has been suggested that the RuO2 will be oxidized to RuO42- and RuO44- in the alkaline solution. These high valency state of the Ru would be reduced to RuO2 while it is discharged.62 The charge storage process occurs mainly in the surface of RuO2, the specific surface, particle size and the amount of combined water of RuO2 materials provide a vital roles in the electrochemical behavior of RuO2 electrode. The higher specific surface of RuO2 materials exists more active centers, providing fast redox reactions and receiving well capacitance. It is an effective
method to coat a thin RuO2 nanofilm onto a rough substrate to increase their surface area. For example, the RuO2 film coated on the surface of MWCNTs electrode is fabricated with high specific capacitance of 628 F/g. 63 The smaller particle size of
RuO2 could also increase the specific surface, shorting the diffusion distance of RuO2 to obtain high capacity. If the size of nanoparticles are controlled, the high

pseudo-capacitances are obtained with increasing the protons transportation and the number of electroactive centers. 64 In addition, the more combined water in
RuO2·xH2O, the better proton diffusion can generate more capacitance. As reported in the literature, the capacitance of RuO2·0.5H2O is 900 F/g, of which decreased to 29 F/g of RuO2·0.03H2O.65 The water content in RuO2·xH2O is highly dependent on the preparation process and conditions. Generally, the water content in RuO2·xH2O could be controlled by the chemically method or sol-gel process, which is decreased with increasing annealing temperature (proper temperature with 116 °C).66 It has been
proposed that it is efficient for proton permeation into the bulk RuO2 with the hydrous regions, and the interconnected RuO2 is region devoted to the electronic transform.
However, RuO2 is expensive, which limits its commercial applications. As charges storage of pseudocapacitor mainly occurs at the electrode-electrolyte interface on RuO2 materials, there are several effective methods to improve the performance of RuO2 electrodes, such as increasing the electroactive surface of electrode and combining with
other excellent cheap electrode materials. Therefore, many researchers devoted to
integrate the RuO2 nanoparticles with carbon nanomaterials, other transition metal oxides (MnO2, Fe3O4, NiO, etc.) and conducing polymers, further improving the electrochemical activity.67 For instance, RuO2/graphene-coated Cu foil electrode is fabricated by using a cathodic electroplating technique. The electrode shows high specific
capacitance of 1561 F/g (0.015 F/cm) without significantly decrease under the bending condition.68, 69 The high cost of RuO2 electrode materials facilitate it only can be applied in the military and aerospace fields.

2.2.2. MnO2 nanoparticles. As a compete alternative, manganese oxide (MnO2) electrode materials exhibit distinguished properties with high specific capacitance, natural
abundance and environmental compatibility for flexible supercapacitors. In 1999, Lee et
al. firstly found that the MnO2 electrode materials exhibit pseudocapacitive behavior in aqueous electrolytes. The specific capacitance of MnO2 electrode materials can reach to 200 F/g.70 It has been reported that different crystals of MnO2 nanoparticles (α-, β-, γ- and δ-MnO2, Fig. 3a-d) are synthesized by using various methods, such as the hydrothermal reaction,71 co-precipitation,72 sol-gel,73 and electrochemical deposition.74 The capacitance of the MnO2 materials depend strongly on their crystalline structures, and the capacitance decreases according to α-MnO2 > δ-MnO2 > γ-MnO2 >β-MnO2.75, 76 At the same time, various morphologies of MnO2, including nanowires, nanotubes, nanobelts, nanoflowers, dendritic clusters, etc., have been successfully synthesized.77-79 Generally, there are two categories of the MnO2 electrode material for supercapacitors application, one is the powder electrode
material, another is the film electrode material. The focus of research on powder
electrode materials is to prepare MnO2 powders with high specific capacitance and high activity.80-82 For example, the capacitance of prepared ultrafine MnO2 nanowire networks with large surface area is 279 F/g, which is larger than that of MnO2 nanotubes and MnO2 nanoneedles (220-233F/g).83-85 The proposed reason is that the diameter of nanowires is less than 10 nm, increasing the large specific surface and
providing more active sites for charge transferring. Another extraordinary MnO2 morphology is two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets. For example, an 2D structure

This electrode shows high specific capacitance of 774 F /g.86 Thin film MnO2 electrodes refer to the deposition of MnO2 directly on the substrate by a certain method with high specific capacitance. The thin structure could increase contact chance of the electrolyte and
the material, improving the ions migration rate. For example, the novel MnO2 hydrates film electrodes via sol-gel-derived method is prepared. The specific capacitance values of this electrode can reach to 698 F/g.87
In spite of high specific capacitance of MnO2 has achieved (about 100-700 F/g), it is still less than 50% of the theoretical value (1370 F/g) due to the large resistivity and the
equivalent series resistance. Various literatures demonstrate that the combining of MnO2 with a conducting additive could construct a composite materials and overcome aforementioned disadvantage, including carbon materials,88, 89 conducting polymers,90 metal oxides,91 etc. For instance, 2D δ-MnO2 integrated on graphene are developed to build hybrid materials for flexible supercapacitors, in which ions could transport the
interface. The specific capacitance of the obtained electrode is 267 F/g and the cyclic performance efficiency remained 92% after 7000 cycles.92 Adding conductive polymers
is also a valid strategy to boost the electrochemical performance of MnO2 electrode. For example, a flake-like structure of MnO2 nanomaterials is fabricated by growing on the carbon fibers, which also wrapped by poly[3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene] (PEDOT) to
enhancing the electrochemical performance of MnO2 electrodes. The RCFs/MnO2/PEDOT composite electrode achieved prominent capacitance of 922 F/g with stable cycle performance that there no significant capacitance decrease after 5000

2.2.3 Fe2O3/Fe3O4 nanoparticles. Iron oxides (e.g., Fe2O3, Fe3O4) are prominent electrode material because of the high theoretical capacity (3625 F/g for α-Fe2O3), natural abundance and environmental friendliness. In general, there exhibits various phases of iron
oxides including α-Fe2O3 (diamond structure), β-Fe2O3 (orthorhombic structure ), γ-Fe2O3 (cubic structure) and Fe3O4.95, 96 The electrochemical performance of Fe2O3 electrodes depends mainly on its crystal structure, particle size and surface morphology.97 Therefore,
various nanostructured materials are also manufactured to improve the electrochemical performance of electrode materials, such as nanofibers,98 nanorods,99, 100 and nanoflowers.101, However, the specific capacitance of prepared iron oxide electrodes is
generally ranged from 5 F/g to 138 F/g on account of the poor electrical conductivity,
which is far below the theoretical value. The porous nanostructured materials have been
intensely investigated, which can improve the electrolyte diffusion rate. For example, the
porous α-Fe2O3 nanostructures are synthesized, the discharge capacitance is more than 300 F/g.102, 103 Recently, a mesoporous Fe2O3 electrode is synthesized via robust solvent deficient method. The specific capacitance of this electrode is 469 F/g.104
Apart from aforementioned designing structures, the introduced deficient can improve
2-5 times the conductivity and offer abundant active sites for electrochemical actions of

the Fe2O3 electrode materials (Fig. 4a-f).105, 106 For example, the α-Fe2O3 nanorods with oxygen deficient are prepared by thermal decomposition method under the condition of N2 (denoted as N-Fe2O3 nanorods). Comparing with that pristine α-Fe2O3 nanorods prepared in air, the areal capacitance of the N-Fe2O3 nanorods is 382.7 mF/cm2. After 10000 cycles, the capacitance still retains 95.2%, showing outstanding stability.97
However, the iron oxide electrode is suffered from poor cycling performance because of
low conductivity and morphology collapse during charging/discharging process.
Combining Fe2O3 with conductive carbon materials or polymers also is an effective strategy to increase the conductivity of electrode. For instance, a nanocomposite
architecture is prepared, in which a mass of Fe2O3 nanoparticles uniformly deposited on the surface of MWNTs. This electrode materials exhibits high specific capacitance of 787 F/g. The capacity of the electrode is still remained of 91.6% after 5000 cycles.107 Another
leaves-like PPy combining with Fe2O3 electrode is also prepared. The specific capacitance can reach to 1167.8 F/g due to the remarkable conductivity of PPy.108
In addition, Fe3O4 often serve as electrode for flexible supercapacitors with preferable electrical conductivity (200 S/cm), wide operating potential window and
environmental-friendly feature. In the early report, the capacitive behavior of Fe3O4 powders is small of 5.3 F/g.109 Subsequently, Fe3O4 film is prepared with uniform cubic structure by a simple hydrothermal process. This Fe3O4 film electrode exhibits specific capacitance of 118.2 F/g.110 Another Fe3O4 nanowire electrodes also is manufactured with capacitance of 190 F/g in an aqueous electrolyte.111
However, the aggregation of Fe3O4 nanoparticle electrode materials lead to decreasing

For example, ultrafine Fe3O4 nanoparticles (5-10 nm) are synthesized with reductant of the ethanolamine (ETA). The addition of ETA and ultrasound process are considered to be crucial to
facilitate the dispersibility and improve capacitance of the Fe3O4 nanoparticles. The high specific capacitance of as-synthesized Fe3O4 nanoparticles is 207.7 F/g at current of 0.4 A/g.112 Another promising way is incorporate Fe3O4 nanostructures with carbon-based materials to solve the above problem, enhancing the electrochemical performance of Fe3O4 electrodes. For instance, the excellent Fe3O4/biocarbon composites electrode materials are developed. The specific capacitance of this electrodes is high to 342 F/g. In addition, after
1000 cycles, the capacity of this electrode still remains 89.5%, showing outstanding cycle stability.113 To enhance the electrochemical performance of Fe3O4/carbon composite, the combination between carbon and Fe3O4 should be enhanced. For instance, a Fe3O4 nanosheets is prepared in situ encapsulated by graphene layers (denoted as G@Fe3O4). The high capacitance of the fabricated G@Fe3O4 electrode without any organic binder is 732 F/g at 2 A/g.114 This graphene coating way not only protect active Fe3O4 aggregation but also form Fe-O-C bonds, resulting in generate strong chemical connection between
Fe3O4 and the graphene to obtain outstanding performance.

electrochemical performance of Fe3O4 electrode materials. The metal ion doping (such as Mn2+, Co2+, etc.) improves the charge storage performance of the electrode by enhancing

2.2.4. NiO/Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles. Among the various transition metal oxides, the nickel oxides (NiO) are fascinating electrode materials with the high theoretical specific
capacitance (2573 F/g), low cost, easy synthesis and environmental-friendly feature.
In general, the NiO materials are usually prepared by using nickel hydroxide
(Ni(OH)2). The Ni(OH)2 also exhibits excellent capacitance properties with theoretical values of 2082 F/g. The energy storage mechanism of NiO and Ni(OH)2 is mainly caused by the reversible redox reaction of Ni2+ and Ni3+, which is showing as follows:121

capacitance (390 F/g) of porous NiO nanocolumns electrode materials is larger than
that both of nanoplates (285 F/g) and nanoslices (176 F/g) at the same current density of 5 A/g (Fig. 5d-f).125, 127 It proved that the construction of porous structure electrode

hierarchical or hollow structural electrode, which is better for ions transportation to

However, the high resistivity of NiO electrode limits its electrochemical performance.
The effective way is combined NiO electrode with a conductive carbon material. For
example, a flexible single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) film decorated with
NiO nanoparticles is prepared. The specific capacitance of this composite electrode
can reach up to 1422 F/g. The capacitance of electrode material still maintains 100% after 500 bending cycles, displaying excellent flexibility.129, 130
Comparing with NiO electrode materials, various literatures demonstrated that Ni(OH)2 materials possess higher specific capacitance.131, 132 For example, a flower nanostructures
of Ni(OH)2 with ultra-thin nanoflakes (7.4 nm) electrode materials are developed. The specific capacitance of this ultra-thin nanostructures electrode is 1715 F/g (scan rate of 5 mV/s).133 Subsequently, an ultra-thin Ni(OH)2 nanosheets growth on the surface of nickel foam substrate electrode is synthesized as 3D structure. This electrode exhibits specific
capacitance of 2384.3 F/g (current density of 1 A/g ) with significant cycling ability (remained 75% after 3000 cycles).134 In addition, amorphous Ni(OH)2 material possesses excellent electrochemical performance that may be available in supercapacitor
applications. Therefore, a mesoporous structure of Ni(OH)2 nanobox is synthesized with

sections.heading: 2.3. Conducting polymer electrode materials
sections.text:
As a promising electrode material of flexible supercapacitor, the conducting polymers
capacitance is mainly derived from Faraday capacitors. The conjugated structure of
conductive polymer could improve the delocalization of electrons and exhibit better conductivity.138 The prominent conductive feature of polymer structure is realized by rapid reversible n-type or p-type element doping.139 Therefore, conductive polymer electrode
materials gradually become the research hotspots, including PANI, polypyrrole (PPy),
PEDOT and their derivatives.
PANI of p-doping shows better performance and widely used because of the low
potential potentials of n-doping PANI. In general, there are two effective strategy to
develop the electrochemical performance of PANI electrode materials. One is to
improve the stable structure and morphology of conductive polymers. The another is
to composite with other materials. For example, the capacitance of as-synthesized PANI
nanofibers electrode is 554 F/g at 1.0 A/g. However, the capacitance of the electrode
rapidly decreases with continuous cycling test. To solve this problem, the multi-walled
carbon tubes (MWCNTs) are introduced to combine with PANI. This electrode materials shows specific capacitance of 606 F/g.140 In addition, the doping of transition metal elements is another promising method.141 For example, a film electrode materials is prepared by Mn doping PANI. The specific capacitance of this electrode is 474 F/g.142 In subsequent research, the Co143, Cu144 and Au145 are also doped into PANI to improve the

PPy attracts more and more attentions because of its better flexibility, and could provide well performance with a smaller volume.146, 147 For example, PPy hydrogel electrodes with
3D porous microstructure are prepared by an interfacial polymerization method. Its specific capacitance is 380 F/g (areal capacitance of 6.4 F/cm2).148 Moreover, PPy are
often deposited onto the surface of carbon materials to fabrication electrode materials. For
example, PPy/MWCNT composite exhibits exceptional high value of 890 F/g in 1.0 M KCl electrolyte.149
PEDOT is a new polythiophene derivative material. It can satisfy the performance
of capacitors with higher electrical conductivity (300-500 S/cm), which is larger than the PANI (0.1-5 S/cm) and the PPy (10-50 S/cm).150 The fast kinetics of PEDOT is
mainly contribute to its high surface area, increasing the ion insertion processes, and
thus enhancing the performance of PEDOT for supercapacitor electrodes. For
example, a porous PEDOT nanoarray electrode material is prepared via controlled electro-polymerization process, presenting capacitance of 109.3 F/g.151 Then, the TiO2 and TiN are coated onto the surface of PEDOT nanoarray to improve the performance
of porous PEDOT nanoarray, The composite PEDOT-TiN and PEDOT-TiO2 electrode shows specific capacitance are 393.1 F/g and 128.7 F/g at 1.0 mA/cm2,
respectively. The PEDOT-TiN electrode is used to construct flexible supercapacitor, which could light on a LED under folding up to 180°.152 The another PEDOT/carbon
composite electrode materials have been explored, providing excellent mechanical
properties. For instance, Sohn et al. grown the PEDOT onto porous multilayered

PEDOT/3D GF). The specific capacitance of this improved PEDOT/3D GF electrode in 1 M H2SO4 is 522 F/g at 2 mA/cm2.153 However, the poor solubility of PEDOT is the mainly limitation in the fabrication of flexible supercapacitors.154 The
polystyrenesulfonate (PSS) are employed to solve the solubility issue of PEDOT, however, this method maybe reduce the conductivity of the PEDOT.155 Consequently,
the introducing of lignosulfonate serves both as a dopant and surfactant to enhance polymeric dispersions.156 The employing surfactant-free method to fabricate dispersible PEDOT microspheres157 and the applying water-soluble version of the copolymer are also generally used to improve the problem.158, 159
The cycling instability is another major obstacle for conductive polymer electrodes in
practical application because of the structural collapses in the charge-discharge cycling. To
address the above issue, researchers attempted to synthesize carbon or MnO2 modification composites as electrodes. The synergistic effects between polymer and other carbon or
metal oxides materials can develop the electrochemical performance of PEDOT. For
example, the carbonaceous shell coated polymer electrodes with ∼5 nm thickness of
shell are prepared, the capacitance of composite materials retains ∼95% after 10000
cycles, which is significantly higher than the pure PPy electrodes (∼85% after 10000
cycles). The strategy may offer a new horizon for fabricating stable flexible polymer electrodes of pseudocapacitive devices.160 The conductive polymer electrode material
has become a research hot spot due to its superior performance, lower cost and rapid
discharging behaviors. It will make a great contribution in the development of flexible

Many significant efforts have been made to develop advanced electrode materials with
higher energy and higher power densities for flexible supercapacitors. We outline the
preparation and properties of carbon materials, metal oxide materials and conducting
polymer electrode materials and discuss the strategies of the structure design to improve on
electrochemical performance. Table 1 shows a summary of the electrochemical properties
of these electrode materials for supercapacitor applications.
The carbon materials are mainly contributed to the EDLCs. However, because of the
electrostatic adsorption of the charge storage process, there has low actual capacitance (<
200 F/g) of carbon materials with high specific area. Then, activating of physics (CO2, H2O) and chemistry (KOH, NaOH, ZnCl2), doping of heteroatoms and depositing onto the porous substrate, are developed to improve the capacitance properties of the carbon
electrode material with large pore structure and surface area. There is a general agreement
that the small pore size (< 2 nm) of carbon materials can increase the specific surface area,
and amount of micropore (pores wider than 2 nm) can enhance the supply of electrolyte. In
order to further improve the electrochemical performance of carbon-based electrode, the
composites that combination with transition metal oxides and conducting polymer also is a
promising choice.
For metal oxide electrode materials, the pseudocapacitance contributes the faradaic
reactions of the electrode materials, which is 10-100 times value higher than that of carbon
materials. The proper material optimizations like designing surface layering, increasing
physically and chemically bonded water and lowing the internal electrical resistance, are

favored to enhance the electrochemical performance of metal oxide electrode. Comparing
to metal-oxides materials, conducting polymers are another pseudocapacitor electrodes,
which exhibit relatively large specific capacitance. For example, the PANI is the more
significant electrodes with higher capacitance (up to 1500 F/g) among conducting
polymers, due to its easy preparation, excellent electrical conductivity and environmental stability.161 Not only the redox reaction, but also chemistry absorption reactions of the
conducting polymer electrode material can enhance the capacitance. Therefore, it is benefit
to provide more redox active site and increase the specific capacitance of these electrode
materials. However, the fast and reversible redox reactions in metal-oxides and conducting
polymers will cause the unstable cyclability. Therefore, the combining with carbon
electrode materials could exhibit the synergistic effect of the both materials. The
pseudocapacitor materials provide excellent capacitance, while carbon materials act as
a framework maintain stable performance during the charge/discharge cycle. As for
the hybrid material system for the development of electrodes, the more effort is to
strengthen the connection between carbon materials and the pseudocapacitive
materials. The effective combination of these electrode materials may promote the new
generation of supercapacitors electrodes with excellent electrochemical performance in the
future.

sections.heading: 3. The structure design for flexible supercapacitors
3.1. Fiber-like flexible supercapacitor
sections.text:
The fibrous flexible supercapacitor is different from the traditional flexibility planar
supercapacitor, which not only possess the higher power density, faster charge/discharge
efficiency and longer cycle life, but also can meet the miniaturization and integration
requirement for flexible wearable electronics. The production of fibrous flexible
supercapacitors is mainly depended on the generation of flexible fibrous electrodes. Many
materials have been used for the preparation of fibrous electrodes, such as metal wire,
carbon fiber, polymer fiber and composite fiber. For example, a fibrous supercapacitor is
prepared by using ZnO nano-wires covered with gold film electrodes, serving as a
high-efficiency prototype for fiber flexible supercapacitor. The prepared fiber supercapacitor exhibits the energy and power density in gel electrolyte is about 2.7 × 108 Wh/cm2 and 1.4 × 105 W/cm2, respectively. Interestingly, the explored fiber supercapacitor displays large power supply, which is enough to be used in self-powering systems.170 In
spite of metal wires, carbon fiber materials are also used as a collector for preparing the
fiber flexible supercapacitor. For example, a CNT sheets fiber-shaped supercapacitor is
developed. The specific capacitance of this fiber supercapacitor is ranged from 42 F/g
to 80 F/g, which retaining 18 F/g after stretching by 75% strains for 100 cycles (Fig.
6a). The admirable flexible has been devoted for developing fiber-based

supercapacitors, however, the low capacitance and energy density can dissatisfy the practical applications of fiber flexibel supercapacitor.171 Then, the MnO2 is introduced as a promising electrode material to boost the performance of flexible fibre
supercapacitors. For instance, the prepared carbon fiber fabric/MnO2 hybrid electrodes possessed outstanding electrochemical supercapacitive propertie with
specific capacitance of 467 F/g and even no significant decrease after 5000 cycles. The energy density of the electrode is 20 Wh/kg.172 Furthermore, a better performance
MnO2@poly(acrylic acid) (PAA)/PPy composite nano-fibers are fabricated by electrospun method. The MnO2@PAA/PPy fiber electrode exhibits specific capacity of 564 F/g at 10 mV/s without decrease after 5000 cycles.173
Because of the excellent flexibility of fiber-shaped supercapacitor, it is possible to
integrate it with other energy storage devices. It is necessary to integrate multiple fiber
devices to improve the limited energy and power density of a single fiber supercapacitor.
For example, a fiber flexible supercapacitor is fabricated with commercial pen ink and
plastic fiber electrodes (Fig. 6b). The areal capacitance, energy density and power density of this fabricated fiber supercapacitor device is 11.9-19.5 mF/cm2, 1.76 × 106-2.70 × 106 Wh/cm2 and 9.07 mW/cm2, respectively. The pen ink is also composed by graphite carbon
nanoparticles and dip-coating on the fibers as electrode which remains steady cycling life after 15000 cycles.174 To further broaden the application of fiber flexible supercapacitors,
the polymer solar cells (served as photovoltaic conversion (PC) part) are integrated with
flexible “energy fiber” (served as energy storage (ES) part) to realize the need for
self-powered device (Fig. 6c). For the ES device, the TiO2 nanotube-modified Ti wire is

efficiency value of the photoelectric conversion and storage can reach up to 0.82%.
After bending 100 times, the efficiency of this fiber devices shows excellent
performance with decrease 10% of the initial. In addition, these "energy fibers" can be
easily woven with other fibers to form flexible textiles, which may provide new ideas for future optoelectronic wearables application.175 Another attempt is to fabricate textile
electrodes of fiber flexible supercapacitors. For example, a lightweight flexible textile
supercapacitor is fabricated by using MWCNT/PANI composite fiber-based electrode.
The specific capacitances of this textile supercapacitor is 272.7 F/g. Even after bending
for 200 cycles, there is no significant capacity decrease (Fig. 6d-f). It provides an effective
strategy for the construction of wearable electronic devices and extends its application in wearable supercapacitors.176 These fiber flexible supercapacitors are made by
depositing electrode material onto a flexible fiber substrate. At the same time, the
electrode material and the substrate may be suffering from the mechanical damage
caused by deformation or cutting, resulting in the electronic device being destroyed in
practical applications. Therefore, a self-healing supercapacitor is developed with high
stretchable by using PPy/RGO/MWCNT fiber springs. This fiber supercapacitor can
be easily stretched to 100% with capacity retention of 82.4%. After cutting and
healing, the capacitance of the device remains no obvious decrease and 54.2% even after the third healing.177 A more efficient method for preparation of self-healing fiber
supercapacitor is proposed that can reconnecting and rearranging the broken yarn

sections.heading: 3.2. Paper/fabric-like supercapacitor
sections.text:
The paper-like flexible supercapacitor can be exploited for wearable electronic
applications because of its natural abundance, high flexible and environmental-friendly
features. Combined with the technology of printed electronics, the printed paper-like
flexible supercapacitor is a prominent alternative to conventional supercapacitors for future
flexible energy application. The fibers in the paper flexible supercapacitor could provide
excellent mechanical properties because of the strong intermolecular and intramolecular
hydrogen bonding forces. Moreover, the CNTs, graphene and PEDOT are introduced in
the paper electrodes of flexible supercapacitors for enhancing electrochemical performance.180, 181 In general, there are two types of the facile paper flexible
supercapacitors: (1) the functional conductive cellulose or graphene paper-based flexible
supercapacitors, which are often prepared by physical and chemical methods, (2) printed
electrodes-based flexible supercapacitors, which are fabricated by inkjet printing, screen
printing, gravure printing, etc.
The graphite paper-based flexible supercapacitors have attracted researchers because of
excellent conductivity and mechanical properties. For example, a graphite flexible paper-based flexible supercapacitor with capacitance of 260 F/g (15.6 mF/cm2) is prepared
(Fig. 7a). This supercapacitor shows excellent cycle stability (retain >99% capacitance after 10000 cycles) and its energy density can reach up to 8.8 Wh/kg.182, 183 However, the
drawbacks of irreversible agglomeration and restacking of graphene nanosheets can
decrease the specific capacitance and bring unstable cycling stability of graphene-based
paper flexible supercapacitor. To solve this problem, MnO2 and PANI active electrode

nanomaterials are usually added into the reduced graphene oxide (rGO) paper. At the
current density of 1.0 A/g, the specific capacitance of the rGO/MnO2/PANI electrode can elevate to 636.5 F/g.184 Apart from the graphene paper, cellulose/conductive material
composite paper is also used to construct the flexible supercapacitor. For example, a
flexible highly conducting PEDOT paper with a conductivity of 375 S/cm is prepared. This PEDOT paper flexible supercapacitor shows an energy density of 1 mWh/cm3.
Furthermore, a 3.6 V interdigital supercapacitor is constructed by three capacitors for high energy application.185 Another Ni(OH)2/graphene/bacterial cellulose paper electrode is fabricated for flexible supercapacitor. The areal capacitance of the electrode is 10.44 F/cm2
(877.1 F/g). After 15000 cycles, the capacitance of this electrode retains 93.6%, exhibiting
promising cycling stability. Even bending to 180° and suffering 48.8 MPa strength (at wet state), this paper electrode also exhibits stable electrochemical performance.186
Printed flexible supercapacitor is a promising electronic that utilized the printing
techniques for the manufacture of supercapacitor, growing rapidly in recent. This printed
flexible supercapacitor has the character of mass production, flexibility, low cost and pattern designation.187, 188 Various printing methods has used to fabricate the paper supercapacitor.189 But the developing of compatible printable inks remains a major challenge.190 For example, the SWCNTs and graphene inks have been used in the
preparation of paper-based flexible supercapacitor. The SWCNTs conductive ink is
formulated and printed as current collectors and electrodes to fabricate flexible paper
supercapacitor. The specific capacitance of this all-printed paper flexible supercapacitor is 200 F/g. Furthermore, this device could maintain stable cycling life over 40000 cycles.191

Another interesting conducive paper is prepared by inkjet printing the activated
carbon/CNTs ink onto the surface of commercial paper. The obtained high capacitance of the device is 100 mF/cm2 without significant decrease over 10000 cycles. The diverse
printed patterns of paper supercapacitor as an energy device could drive LED illumination. 192
Recently, the developed direction of flexible supercapacitors in human wearable devices
are tended to prepare comfortable and breathable electronic devices. Therefore, textile or
fabric based flexible supercapacitors with the lightweight and mechanical flexibility are
proven to be the strong candidates for making wearable powering supplies. According to
the literature, there are two types of fabric flexible supercapacitors. One is the flexible
textile supercapacitor, weaving by cotton fibers or yarns (modified with conductive
materials). Another is the printed supercapacitors, which printed the electrode materials
directly onto the textile substrates. The flexible textile supercapacitors are attracted more
interest because of their small volumes and easy integrated into desired shape. For
example, an all-solid-state flexible yarn supercapacitor is reported by coating the Ni layer
and rGO onto the surface of yarns (denoted as rGO-Ni-yarn). This rGO-Ni-yarn electrode
is integrated with a triboelectric nanogenerator cloth (TENG) for self-charging power application. This device obtains high capacitances of 72.1 mF/cm2.193 Afterwards, a
flexible and washable yarn supercapacitor is prepared by using the carbon nanofibers and
PEDOT:PSS coated carbon fibers. The flexible supercapacitor is knitted into the TENG
fabric to construct the self-charging power device. The power density of TENG fabric supercapacitor is ∼85 mW/m2. After being washed, the TENG fabric device still can light

and MnO2 nanosheets as active electrode materials. The specific capacitance of the all-printed flexible supercapacitors is 19.23 mF/cm2. Moreover, after bending and twisting 100 times, the device still maintains stable electrochemical performance.165 The inkjet
printing method are also used to fabricate all‐solid‐state flexible paper
supercapacitors. The areal capacitance of printed interdigitated finger flexible supercapacitor is as high as 52.9 mF/cm2 by using hierarchical structure of Ni@MnO2 electrode materials. In spite of the excellent flexibility and electrochemical stability of
the printed devices, the large-scale artistic supercapacitors displayed desirable attributes for future portable and wearable devices.195 The printing method is
introduced to the fabrication of flexible supercapacitors, satisfying the requirements
for researchers to make larger-scale devices.

sections.heading: 3.3. Foam-like flexible supercapacitor
sections.text:
The fiber-like and paper-like flexible supercapacitors display outstanding gravimetric
capacitances, energy densities and power densities. However, the energy outputs of a
fiber-like or paper-like flexible supercapacitor are very limited. Therefore, foam-like
supercapacitor with 3D porous structure are developed to fabricate high-performance
supercapacitors, achieving higher energy outputs. The 3D porous structures are beneficial
for electrode materials because of this structure can provide large specific surface area, and
the hierarchical porous structure accelerates to electrolyte ion immersion. In general, 3D
microporous frameworks are prepared by using the carbon materials or carbon/polymers
composite materials. For instance, a 3D macroporous structural supercapacitors are

fabricated by using the chemically modified graphene and adding MnO2 layer to boost the capacitance (Fig. 8a-b). This porous graphene structure electrode materials shows specific
capacitance of 389 F/g at 1 A/g. Moreover, the energy and power density of this assembled flexible supercapacitor is 44 Wh/kg and 25 kW/kg, respectively.199 Conducting polymers
have also been fabricated for porous flexible supercapacitor because of their easy
fabrication and large pseudo-capacitance. A general approach is to prepare and utilize 3D
porous carbon materials with high surface area. For example, GO-induced porous
core-like PPy/PET had been fabricated for flexible supercapacitor. This device shows the
specific capacitance and energy density of 568.35 F/g and 37.4 Wh/kg at 0.1 A/g,
respectively. In addition, the capacitance retain 83.4% after 500 cycles, showing stable cycle capacity200 Another carbon foam electrode is developed by grown ultrathin MnO2 on the surface of carbon (Fig. 8d-e). The specific capacitance and energy density of this
fabricated MnO2/carbon foam supercapacitor is 1270.5 F/g and 86.2 Wh/kg, respectively.201 Apart from 3D macoporous structure, the flexible and robust sponge-like
structure also are utilized to manufacture the porous flexible supercapacitor. The splendid
metal-organic frameworks (MOF)-derived porous carbon materials are prepared for flexible supercapacitor. This electrode material with 1356 m2/g high specific surface area,
of which the specific capacitance can reach up to 369 F/g at 400 mV/s. After 2000 bending
cycles, the porous flexible supercapacitor device remains 96% capacity, which still can power red LEDs for more than 10 minutes.202 These porous 3D structures of flexible
supercapacitors could facilitate the transport of electrons lead to low electrical
resistance and high capacitance.

sections.heading: 4. Application for wearable flexible devices
sections.text:
The smart wearable electronics have caught research interest recently. Therefore, the
development of flexible power source is one of the important issues to ensure the using of

wearable products in daily life. Flexible supercapacitors are developed as the most
prominent energy storage devices for wearable application because of their excellent
safety and fast charging/discharging performance. Another trend is to integrate the flexible
supercapacitor into the multifunction wearable platform for further applications in smart
medical, sports and fitness, military, smart furniture, entertainment, etc.
Solar cells have broad applications in the wearable field because of continuously energy
providing for wearable devices under light illumination. However, solar cells can not work
properly at night. Therefore, a single energy harvesting device is difficult to implement on
wearable devices, the supercapacitors become an ideal auxiliary energy supply. For
example, Cai et al. prepared a flexible carbon micro-supercapacitor, which could amplify
voltage and capacitance by connecting the single supercapacitor in parallel or in series. A
self-powered system is successfully prepared with solar panel as an energy harvester, the flexible supercapacitor as an energy storage part which can power a digital clock.206 In
addition, a self-charging power device has developed by incorporating flexible transition
metal carbides (MXenes) supercapacitors with human motion energy harvest module,
which could drive variety of electronics and sensors. The specific capacitance of this flexible supercapacitors is 23 mF/cm2. After 10000 cycles, there exists 95% capacitance.207
The self-power supply system described above can realize the energy storage of flexible
supercapacitor, assisting by conversion of power generation that makes it practical for
wearable device application.
Another wearable functional device is assembly by various sensors and flexible
supercapacitors to achieve the functions of multiple signal detection and energy storage.

For instance, a fiber flexible device is fabricated, integrating with supercapacitor and
optical detector. This device could generate current under light illumination and then charging by the flexible supercapacitor.208 In addition, a dual-mode sensor is produced by
using PPy/GF electrode material for flexible supercapacitor and PDMS/PPy/GF as pressure/temperature sensors materials (Fig. 9a-c).209 The areal capacitance of this flexible supercapacitor is 89.6 mF/cm2 at 0.6 mA/cm2. The manufactured dual mode
sensor can detect the signals of pressure and temperature simultaneously. It exhibits high
sensitivity, fast response/recovery and high durability during 10000 pressure cycles. The
multifunctional platforms are constructed by integrating the supercapacitors with
functional sensors extend the applications of flexible supercapacitor.
Self-healing materials (most of polymeric materials) are a class of materials that have
self-monitoring and self-healing properties that can repair external damage. In practical
applications, supercapacitors with self-healing characteristic are highly desirable for
flexible and implantable electronic devices. In order to achieve the self-healing flexible
supercapacitors, a great deal of effort has been devoted to design of various electrodes,
electrolytes and substrates. There are two main types of healing mechanisms: one is
compounded with functional self-healing materials; the other is self-healing by providing
energy to trigger covalent or non-covalent bonding of the material. Recently, an intrinsic
self-healing electrolyte (polyacrylic acid-vinyl hybrid silica nanoparticles, VSNPs-PAA)
based on hydrogen bonding is designed to assemble the flexible supercapacitor. The PPy is
uniformly electrodeposited on the CNT paper as the electrode. This self-healing
supercapacitors can maintain 100% capacitance with 20 break/healing cycles, which is

sections.heading: 5. Outlook and Perspectives
sections.text:
The excellent flexible supercapacitors are desirable for wearable electronic devices
because of its long life, excellent mechanical properties, high charge/discharge efficiency
and energy density. As the core component of supercapacitors, the electrode materials
have been studied more and more widely in recent years. The foregoing discussions
illustrate that the carbon material electrodes are the first appeared for flexible
supercapacitor, followed by metal oxide electrodes, and polymer electrodes. We reviewed
the different electrode materials and clarified the effective tactics of electrode construction
for flexible solid-state supercapacitors. The performances of the current electrode materials
are still unsatisfactory, and thus the high-performance, stable and environment friendly
electrode materials should be exploited in the future. In addition, the current progresses
on the fiber-, paper/fabric- and foam-like flexible supercapacitor are reviewed.
Despite significant advances obtained in the field of flexible supercapacitors, several
future research directions are suggested as following:
(1) To explore the novel electrode materials is still a fascinating and continuous
research direction. At present, electrode materials as the significant component of the
flexible supercapacitor including carbons, metal oxide/hydroxides and conducting
polymers materials have made significant progress in the past. Recently, the MOF is a promising functional electrode material with very high specific areas of 46000 m2/g.
The Ni-MOF, Cu-MOF, Co-MOF are generally used in flexible supercapacitors. The
other emerging electrode materials also should arouse extensive attention with high
electronic conductivity and surface porosity such as MXenes, black phosphorousare,

etc.
(2) It is essential to develop and design rational structure of electrode materials to
obtain the high-performance flexible supercapacitor. Various promising strategy are
developed, such as introducing porous structure, increasing interlayer space of
crystalline structure, designing 3D structure, etc. In general, the design of micropores
structure (< 2 nm) of pore-dependent electrode carbon materials is an efficient method
for increasing the capacitance. Another interesting way is to load the active materials
on large surface substrates to form the 3D structure, including synthetic engineering
carbon nano-networks, as well as porous paper and textiles.
(3) Common standards need to be developed to evaluate the performance of flexible
supercapacitors. Various studies use the specific capacitance as a common
comparison parameter to evaluate and compare the performance of these
supercapacitors. However, the mass specific capacitance is not reasonable because
that the amount of active material added to the electrode is negligible compared to the
mass of the micro-device. In addition, the volumetric specific capacitance is also
inaccurately to represent the characteristics of the flexible supercapacitor without
consideration their thicknesses. This measurement exists large error from thin to thick
electrode films. For the micro-features of wearable electronic devices, the coverage
area of the supercapacitors is limited. Therefore, areal capacitance can be achieved for
better characterizing the performance of supercapacitors. Then, a standard should be
developed to assess the performance of flexible supercapacitor, avoiding excessive
specific capacitance calculation.

(4) New technology is necessary explored to fabricate flexible supercapacitor devices.
There are various preparation processes for flexible solid-state supercapacitors, such
as photolithography, electroplating, etc. These processes with complex steps and strict
conditions limit the practical application of flexible supercapacitor in electronic
devices. With the application of inkjet, screen, gravure printing technology in printed
electronics, printing technology opens up a promising preparation method for
supercapacitors. This printed flexible supercapacitor could meet the market demand
for wearable with solid film structure and high resolution of the pattern.
(5) The flexible supercapacitor should be integrated with other functional devices for
multifunctional wearable device application. The new challenging for flexible
supercapacitors is that the developed flexible supercapacitors should integrate into
wearable cloth and electronic devices. Then, there are still challenges to integrate the
flexible supercapacitors with other detection or other function devices for practical
applications. In order to achieve a better compatible application, researchers should
exploit excellent electrode materials with high energy storage performance and search
new the fabrication technology for flexible wearable supercapacitors in future.
Conflicts of interest
There are no conflicts to declare.

J. Liang
Jing Liang received her BS from the Jining Medical University in 2013. She is currently pursuing a PhD degree under the supervision of Prof. Wei Wu in the School of Printing and Packaging at Wuhan University. W. Wu
